para.paratext: The doctrine of judicial notice operates as a substitute for formal proof. It is a method for expediting proof of adjudicative facts that are not reasonably subject to dispute, for simplifying the process of authenticating documents, and for overcoming best evidence problems. Taking judicial notice does not relieve a party of the duty to gather, organize, and present evidence to the court and does not automatically establish the admissibility, relevance, or weight of that evidence.[1] This rule relates to judicial notice of “adjudicative” facts and not “legislative” facts. Professor Kenneth Culp Davis coined this terminology,[2] and its use differs from the United States Supreme Court's use of “legislative” facts in constitutional cases.

In federal courts, Fed. R. Evid. 201 governs judicial notice of adjudicative facts. “Adjudicative facts” are facts that relate specifically to the actions or characteristics of the parties or to the particular case, while “legislative facts” are those which a court relies upon to develop a particular law or policy or which relate to legal reasoning.

Whether a fact is “adjudicative” or “legislative” depends on how the fact is used.[3] Under Rule 201 and O.C.G.A. § 24-2-201, a judicially noticed fact must be one not subject to reasonable dispute in that it is either generally known within the territorial jurisdiction of the court or capable of accurate and ready determination by resort to sources whose accuracy cannot reasonably be questioned.
A court may take judicial notice, whether requested or not.[4] A court must take judicial notice upon request by a party and if provided with the necessary information.[5]

A party is entitled, upon timely request, to a hearing as to the propriety of taking judicial notice and the tenor of the matter noticed.[6] A party may request an opportunity to be heard on the subject of judicial notice after the court has taken notice of a fact, if the party did not receive prior notice of a party's or the court's intention to pursue judicial notice.[7]

A court may take judicial notice at any stage of the proceeding,[8] and in fact, the appellate courts can take judicial notice of subsequent developments in cases that are a matter of public record and relevant to the appeal.[9]

In a civil action or proceeding, the court instructs the jury that it must accept as conclusive any fact judicially noticed. In a criminal case, the court instructs the jury that it may, but is not required to, accept as conclusive any fact judicially noticed.[10]

Judicial notice in federal practice is much the same as in Georgia practice. The court has always had broad discretion in deciding whether the fact in question is a proper fact to receive judicial notice. The federal courts liberally take judicial notice. In Massachusetts v. Westcott,[11] the court took judicial notice of Coast Guard records that showed that the defendant had a fishing license. Courts have taken judicial notice in other areas such as the venue and charges in criminal cases.[12]

Sometimes courts use the terms “judicial cognizance” and “judicial knowledge” as well.[13] A judge may judicially notice facts known to him in his judicial capacity, but not his personal capacity.[14] It must be a fact that any judge sitting on the bench of that court could judicially notice.

The Georgia Court of Appeals has explained that the purpose of judicial notice is to eliminate the need for formal proof as to “(1) matters of which the general public has common knowledge; (2) facts which are readily ascertainable by reference to some reliable source and are beyond dispute; and (3) matters which are within the special province of the judge.”[15]

Generally, appellate courts may take judicial notice of any fact that would be a proper subject of judicial notice by the trial court, even though the record does not show that the trial court took judicial notice of the fact. The Georgia Supreme Court has frequently taken judicial notice of facts that did not appear in the record below.[16]
The present Georgia statute lists a number of matters that can be judicially noticed.[17]

Importantly, the court must give the parties an opportunity to comment before it notices judicially a fact. Thus, it was error for a trial court to notice judicially, after the close of evidence, that a highway had two lanes without providing all parties an opportunity to address its decision to take judicial notice.[18]
The following sections divide the area of judicial notice into four general areas: matters of common knowledge, law, government, and administrative.
In re Hillard Development Corp., 238 B.R. 857, 52 Fed. R. Evid. Serv. 1028 (Bankr. S.D. Fla. 1999).
Davis, Problems of Evidence in the Administrative Process, 55 Harv. L. Rev. 364, 404–407 (1942); and see McCormick on Evidence §§ 331, 359 (6th ed.).

Qualley v. Clo-Tex Intern., Inc., 212 F.3d 1123, 54 Fed. R. Evid. Serv. 874 (8th Cir. 2000); Toth v. Grand Trunk R.R., 306 F.3d 335, 59 Fed. R. Evid. Serv. 756, 54 Fed. R. Serv. 3d 374, 2002 FED App. 0321P (6th Cir. 2002) (holding modified on other grounds by, Roberts ex rel. Johnson v. Galen of Virginia, Inc., 325 F.3d 776, 61 Fed. R. Evid. Serv. 89, 55 Fed. R. Serv. 3d 875, 2003 FED App. 0107P (6th Cir. 2003)).
Serdula v. State, 344 Ga. App. 587, 812 S.E.2d 6 (2018).
Massachusetts v. Westcott, 431 U.S. 322, 97 S. Ct. 1755, 52 L. Ed. 2d 349, 1 Fed. R. Evid. Serv. 1025 (1977).
U.S. v. Anderson, 528 F.2d 590, 1 Fed. R. Evid. Serv. 1121 (5th Cir. 1976); U.S. v. Hughes, 542 F.2d 246 (5th Cir. 1976).
Cf. Comment Note.—Distinction between judicial notice and judicial knowledge, 113 A.L.R. 258.
Fox v. State, 9 Ga. 373, 1851 WL 1440 (1851); 31 C.J.S., Evidence, § 11.
Fitzpatrick v. Harrison, 300 Ga. App. 672, 686 S.E.2d 322 (2009); In re D.W., 318 Ga. App. 725, 734 S.E.2d 543 (2012).
Central R.R. v. DeBray, 71 Ga. 406, 1883 WL 2712 (1883); Benton v. Munday, 183 Ga. 228, 187 S.E. 874 (1936); Liberty Bell Mut. Fire Ins. Co. v. Exum, 209 Ga. 548, 74 S.E.2d 738 (1953).

The existence and territorial extent of states and their forms of government; all symbols of nationality; the laws of nations; all laws and resolutions of the General Assembly and the journals of each branch thereof as published by authority; the laws of the United States and of the several states thereof as published by authority; the uniform rules of the courts; the administrative rules and regulations filed with the Secretary of State pursuant to Code Section 50-13-6; the general customs of merchants; the admiralty and maritime courts of the world and their seals; the political makeup and history of this state and the federal government as well as the local divisions of this state; the seals of the several departments of the government of the United States and of the several states of the union; and all similar matters of legislative fact shall be judicially recognized without the introduction of proof. Judicial notice of adjudicative facts shall be governed by Code Section 24-2-201.
Stewart v. State, 288 Ga. App. 735, 655 S.E.2d 328 (2007).

See also Graves v. State, 269 Ga. 772, 775–776, 504 S.E.2d 679 (1998) (disapproved of on other grounds by, Jones v. State, 272 Ga. 900, 537 S.E.2d 80 (2000)) (requiring that a trial court announce its decision prior to taking judicial notice of any fact and afford the parties an opportunity to be heard regarding whether judicial notice should be taken); Mann v. State, 285 Ga. App. 39, 42, 645 S.E.2d 573 (2007).
